Blog.post: San Francisco, California, 2003 Melissa Williams made one last stop in front of the mirror before leaving for school. Being popular meant she had to look her best everyday of the week. Only one more week âtil summer vacation , she thought. The rest of the âinâ crowd were already gathered in the parking lot. Hannah Ackermann, a shy yet extremely cute blonde girl, her boyfriend; dark haired, dark eyed Danny Fernandez, quarterback of the schoolâs football team; red-headed Celine Baxter and her ever faithful boyfriend, Matt Jefferies; and her childhood best friend, Josh Thompson. Everyone had been expecting them to hook up for ages now. But they just didnât feel that way towards each other. Melissa knew for a fact that Josh was hopelessly in love with someone else. Josh was the first one to spot her. âHey!â âHey. Whereâs A.J.?â âLike that girl ever follows a strict timetable,â said Celine, tossing her hair over her shoulders. âI donât know why we even bother with her.â Melissa never knew why, but Celine and A.J. never got along well. She admitted that Celine could be a real bitch at times and A.J.âs temper often made her unapproachable, but Celine often gave people a chance and A.J. had a kind of aura about her that attracted people. Maybe itâs because A.J.âs new to our gang , thought Melissa. This wasnât the first time the thought went through her mind. A.J. had arrived at the beginning of the previous year. She fit in immediately. Everyone wanted to be near her, and everyone still did. Josh was the one who had brought her into their circles. He had been looking for a new bass player for his band, Evocation . A.J. had a talent unmatched by anyone else. She was also totally indifferent about everything. Just then they heard the roar of a motorbike engine. A black 1999 Yamaha thunder cat thundered into the parking lot, ridden by a black clad figure, barely missing the gang who had to rush out of the way to avoid being run over. âDoesnât that girl ever watch where sheâs going?â fumed Celine. Arianna Jacobs removed her helmet, revealing silken raven black hair cut just below her chin. Her flawless pale skin wasnât even flushed from her ride. Her eyelids were darkened with kohl making her green eyes stand out. Melissa had to admit that A.J. never failed to look good even without trying. A.J.âs small stature often gave people the impression that she was someone who needed to be protected but Melissa knew better than to assume that. âDidnât you see us, freak?â shrieked Celine. âYou got out of the way in time, didnât you?â said Arianna shrugging her shoulders. âWhy donât you â â The school bell drowned out whatever Celine was saying, avoiding the catfight between the two girls. Melissa didnât think that A.J. would have cared, however. The girl was already heading into the school, leaving Celine fuming like she always did when they had a confrontation. It seemed like nothing fazed her. Melissa sighed. Will those two ever get along , she wondered. Arianna didnât know why she bothered with these people. She got along well enough with a few of them, but that red-headed girl wasnât worth her time. There she is right now, complaining to that boyfriend of hers. Really, he behaves more like a faithful dog than a boyfriend. For the billionth time, Arianna wondered why she was even trying to be normal, trying to be human. She just wasnât; not anymore, and hadnât been for a long time. Arianna woke up to find herself enclosed in a tight, dark space. She felt weak â drained â and light-headed. Where am I, she wondered. Her neck felt excruciatingly painful and she touched it gingerly, tracing the two tiny holes there. She blanched as she remembered what happened in the alley. She knew she should be dead yet it seemed the vampire had spared her. Or maybe Iâve become like him, she panicked. She placed a hand over her heart to be sure and felt reassured by her faint but steady heartbeat. Just then she heard a loud scrapping noise. A moment later, she was staring up at the pale face of her captor. âGood morning. Or should I say, good evening.â âWhere am I?â Arianna pushed herself upright, taking in her surroundings. She gasped as she realized that she was lying in a coffin. They were in, what seemed to be, a dank basement, the only lighting being wall-mounted torches. There were no windows that she could see. âHow long have I been asleep?â âTwo days. How are you feeling?â Arianna was surprised by the concern in the vampireâs voice. âUmâ¦Iâm fine. Why have you brought me here?â The vampire smiled. âHow would you like to live forever? To never feel pain again? To have absolute power in your hands?â âWhat?â âIâm offering you immortality.â âWhy?â His smile widened. âYou anger is a great power you could tap into. What Iâm offering you will help you do that. Think of what you could do with that kind of power. All youâll be doing is trading this miserable life youâre living for a much better one.â Arianna fell silent as she contemplated what the vampire was offering. âYouâll be able to do whatever you want and no oneâs ever going to be able to make you do what you donât want to ever again. Youâll no longer be the victim, the world will be your toy, youâll be in controlâ¦â The vampire paused before adding, ââ¦and, if memory serves, there are a few people youâd like to exact revenge on, am I right?â It was Ariannaâs turn to smile. She had made up her mind. She hardly felt the pain this time, giving herself over to the dark. She never even registered her slowing heartbeat. The next thing she knew, Arianna was looking up at a thin red line at the base of the vampireâs throat. âDrink, my love, drinkâ¦â Arianna latched onto his throat and did as he bid. Kristopherâ¦ As she drank, the vampireâs memories flowed freely into herâ¦his transformation, his first killâ¦ then something that surprised her â Kristopher had been stalking her for a while. This wasnât some chance meeting. He had seen her climb out of the orphanage window and had followed her until she realized his presence. He had been prepared to present her with his proposal and had expected her to accept. Arianna wondered what this meant. Darkness sought to have her in its cold embrace again. The last thing Arianna heard was Kristopher whispering, âWelcome to my world, my Katrianaâ¦â Katriana â¦ Arianna hadnât heard that name in a long time and had no desire to ever again. Katriana was part of her old life, one she had left behind long ago. As she entered the hallways of her high school, Arianna registered the strange murmurings of the crowd around her. âA.J.!â It was one of the hangers-on that constantly followed Arianna and the gang. The girlâs name escaped her at the moment. âHave you heard of the attacks?â âWhat attacks?â âYou mean, you donât know?â The girl was obviously ecstatic about being the one to break the news to a member of the âinâ crowd. âIâve been away all week-end. Whatâs going on?â âThere were two attacks over the week-end. People are saying that an animal did it. Itâs horrible.â âCut the dramatics and give me the facts, Georgina.â Thatâs right. The girlâs nameâs Georgina Forbes . âWell, itâs not anyone from school. I canât believe you havenât heard. Itâs been all over the news.â âThere wasnât any form of communication where I was. It was kinda like a back-to-nature thing. So, who were the victims? I assume itâs safe to use the past tense with them.â âOh, perfectly safe. The coroners said they bled to death and there was no way that they would have survived anyway, considering the wounds they received. Horrible, really. At least, it wasnât one of us, right?â Arianna suspected that Georginaâs âusâ wasnât referring to the student body. âWere they from around here?â âWho?â âThe victims of these attacks.â âOh no, apparently they were bums. No need to worry.â Yeah, no need to worry . Arianna had realized that people didnât usually care what happened to the homeless. They were the most obvious choice when it came time to feed. Not that she would take another human life; not after the last timeâ¦ She had been telling the truth about the whole back-to-nature thing. She had been out in the forest, quenching her ever growing appetite. Melissa had caught up with her by then â so had the rest of their little gang. Georgina immediately latched onto Josh trying to get his attention. Hannah seemed unnerved. Then again , Arianna thought, she always does . âSo, Josh, have you heard the latestâ¦â âItâs terrible,â said Melissa aside to Arianna. âYou mean the attacks?â asked Arianna. âNo, itâs the fact that no one seems to care about the victims. Itâs like just because theyâre homeless they have no right to anything. Not even a little respect. The entire schoolâs like gossiping about it.â Arianna smiled. Melissa could be said to be her closest friend in her new life. This is why I like her , she thought. âEveryoneâs saying some animal did it,â said Josh, having extricated himself from Georgina, who was looking rather forlorn. âYou donât sound like you agree,â Arianna commented. âYouâre right, I donât. If the attacks were near some woodlands or something, then maybe this theory about animal attacks is right. But they happened right in the city.â âSo? Animals could wander into the city any time,â argued Celine. Matt nodded in agreement. âAnd the fact that their throats were practically ripped out supports the fact,â he added. Celine smiled approvingly. âAs much as I hate to admit, I agree with Celine on this one,â said Danny. Hannah kept quiet. The late bell rung, cutting short any debate they were about to launch into. âWeâd better get going. Donât want to get detention during this last week,â said Danny, putting an arm around Hannah and guiding her to their first class. âEspecially if you get stuck with Mr. Becker,â muttered Josh. Arianna and Melissa headed for their English class. Mrs. Peterson seemed to be in a holiday mood already and didnât even seem to notice that half the class was late. She also hadnât prepared a lesson. âWeâll just do a little role play, shall we?â There were a few groans from the class as everyone took out their copies of the Shakespearean play they had been studying, Romeo and Juliet. âWhy do teachers always pose things as questions?â whispered Melissa as she leaned over her bag to retrieve her book. âItâs not like we have a say in anything anyway.â âWho knows?â replied Arianna. She was already feeling just as lazy as everyone else was. Fortunately, the role Mrs. Peterson assigned her wasnât huge. Unfortunately, Mrs. Peterson was a perfectionist. âNo, no. Say that again, Arianna. And this time, say it with feeling!â Arianna sighed. She was just about to launch into another mind-numbingly boring monologue, when she was interrupted by the creak of the classroom door swinging open. There, framed by the doorway, was a boy with incredibly blue eyes and hair so blonde it seemed almost white. Kristopherâ¦ Itâs impossible , Arianna thought. Be rationale. His hair and eyes are a different color. Yetâ¦thereâs no mistaking that smile or that faceâ¦No, it canât be. Kristopherâs dead. I should know since I killed himâ¦ âAnd who might you be?â enquired Mrs. Peterson. âDamion Grant,â replied the boy. There, see, it isnât Kristopher. The boyâs got a totally American accent and Kristopherâs too proud to disguise his descent . âWelcome,â said Mrs. Peterson with a flourish. Arianna sometimes wondered about the state of her mental health. Damion just looked amused. Arianna couldnât help but notice that no one was paying much attention to the role playing anymore. Not that anyone really was in the beginning. Everyoneâs attention, including Mrs. Petersonâs, was fixed solely on the new boy. She couldnât help but notice since it was normally she that was the center of everyoneâs attention. By recess, word had gotten around about the new kid in school. Damion was all Celine could talk about. Arianna shook her head in disbelief at Matt, who was hanging on to Celineâs every word and didnât even seem to mind that her attention was totally focused on another boy. Melissa caught her movement and gave a sympathizing smile. âHe is like the hottest guy ever!â exclaimed Celine. Georgina had returned with other hangers-on. All of them were nodding their agreement. âWhat do you think, Matt?â asked Arianna innocently. Melissa tried hard not to laugh. âWhat?â said Matt absent-mindedly. âOh rightâ¦whatever Celine saysâ¦â Josh sighed. âPoor guy,â he said. Just then, Danny and Hannah walked up. âHey, guys,â greeted Danny. âHeard âbout the new kid?â âYeah, thatâs all weâve been hearing,â replied Josh. âCeline wonât shut up!â âHey, A.J., lighten up. Besides, we already know that. Itâs a well known fact.â âHey!â protested Celine. âCan we talk about something else other than Damion?â pleaded Melissa. âRightâ¦soâ¦where are you guys going this summer?â asked Josh. No one had made any plans. âIâve got an idea!â exclaimed Hannah. Heads swerved to face her, surprised that she was even contributing to their conversation. âMy parents are like going to Tahiti this summer. The cottage in the mountains will be free. We could go there. Like just the gang. Itâd be like one long party!â âHmm,â said Danny, nuzzling her neck. âJust what are you planning, Hannah?â Hannah giggled and blushed. âHmm,â said Celine. âUh oh, what are you plotting, Celine?â demanded Melissa. âOh nothing, just wondering if Damion would like to come along.â âI thought this was just the gang,â said Arianna. Celine glared at her. âIt was just a thought. Oh! There he is right now!â Everyone turned to where she was looking and true enough there was Damion Grant entering the schoolâs cafeteria. âI think Iâll go over and invite him.â And before anyone could protest, she had left her seat and was already half-way there. Josh gave an exaggerated moan when she intentionally tossed her hair over her shoulders and started simpering. Arianna and Melissa shared a smile. They watched on as Celine made her proposal and noted Damionâs look of surprise, as well as the smile he gave her. It wasnât exactly the ecstatic smile that other boys gave Celine when they finally manage to get her attention. It was sort of embarrassed and it looked like he was desperately wishing that he was anywhere but there right then. He smiled again, but this time it was more apologetic than embarrassed, and made a hasty escape from the cafeteria. Melissa tried not to smile as Celine dejectedly made her way back. Arianna, however, had no qualms about smiling. Georgina and the other hangers-on were staring at Damionâs retreating back, their mouthâs gaping wide. Georgina turned to Celine. âI canât believe he just blew you off!â âShut up,â Celine muttered dangerously. Georgina must have noted the threatening tone in her voice for she did just as she was told. âSo much for that idea,â said Arianna. âShut up!â Melissa placed a hand on her friendâs shoulder before she could throw herself at Arianna. âA.J., lighten up.â Arianna gave her a look that Melissa couldn't quite interpret, shrugged and let the matter rest. Josh smiled at her, silently thanking her for preventing the imminent fight. Matt didnât seem to know just quite what to do. Both Danny and Hannah tried to pretend they hadnât witnessed anything. âSo,â said Josh a little too cheerfully. âAre we still on for this summer getaway in the mountains?â âDefinitely,â said Danny, casting an affectionate glance at Hannah. âYup,â said Melissa. âOf course,â thundered Celine. âHe doesnât know what heâs missingâ¦â They let her continue fuming and gave her space to calm down in her own time. âWhatever Celine wants,â said Matt. Arianna simply shrugged. âWeâll take that as a yes,â said Melissa. Arianna smiled. âPerfect!â exclaimed Josh. âThis is gonna be so cool!â Melissa smiled at her friendâs enthusiasm and wondered exactly what had caused it.

London, England 1919 Arianna hoisted herself out of the window, reaching in to pull out her bag before dropping to the ground. It was hardly a long fall and she made it without twisting her ankle or worst, breaking her neck. Taking one last look at what had been her prison for the last three years, Arianna made a rude gesture, felt the exhilaration of Mrs. Riley not being able to reprimand her, and turn her back on the orphanage forever. She wondered when they would notice her absence. Probably when they wake us up for the early morning service , she thought. The services were another reason she detested the orphanage. Every morning, Mrs. Riley would wake the children up and they would gather in the common room. Then she would say a prayer for the lost souls and thank God for sparing their lives. Thy will be done on earth as it is in heaven , Mrs. Riley would pray. If God was all-powerful, why couldnât He stop the damn war? Arianna thought bitterly. Why couldnât he have saved Mama and Papa? But most of all, why couldnât He save Robert? Although Robert was five years her senior, she and her brother were always very close. It sometimes seemed that they could even read each others minds. But then the war started and Robert rushed to enlist in the army. Her parents were proud that their son would be defending good olâEngland. To them, it was an honour to have a son fighting in the war. But less than a year later, Robert laid dead, a single bullet hole through his temple. From the minute she heard of her brotherâs death, Ariannaâs health deteriorated. She never was a healthy child to begin with. She was small for her age; her skin was sallow, her features pinched and her greasy dark hair just seemed to weigh her down. Now she began to lose weight until she resembled a walking skeleton. Then her parents were killed in an air raid. Her motherâs brother took her in for awhile, before her constant fits of coughing and doctorâs visits became too much of a burden. She was abandoned at the orphanage at the age of twelve. Mrs. Riley took an instant disliking to her. The feeling was mutual. Despite her ailing health, Mrs. Riley set her a number of tedious tasks; scrubbing the floors, doing the washing, white washing the privy. Ariannaâs face twisted in an ugly scowl as she recalled her years of imprisonment. âPut your back into it, girl! Iâll never for the life of me figure out why I ever took you in. Iâve just got a big heart. And look where thatâs brought me!â Arianna invited her to do something unnatural to herself. She didnât say it out loud, of course, just thought it in her mind. Still Mrs. Riley frowned at her work. âLook at this filth!â Arianna bit her tongue to stop herself from pointing out that she was the one who was trailing filth behind her by failing to remove her boots when she returned from pottering out in the garden. She tried to block out Mrs. Rileyâs voice by thinking of her life before imprisonment and proceeded to scrub the kitchen floor harder. Out of the corner of her eye, she saw Helen, another of the orphans, looking at her with pity. How come I get stuck with scrubbing floors while everyone else does meager work, thought Arianna. She had protested about it before and Mrs. Riley had responded by telling her that such work would humble her haughty attitude and curb her anger. Arianna readily admitted that she was a tempestuous child but felt that Mrs. Riley was really exaggerating by calling her haughty. She helped whenever she could and never thought ill of anyone until she came to the orphanage. Right then she was praying that some unfortunate accident might happen to Mrs. Riley. âHurry up, girl! Really you should stop being so lazy!â That did it. âWhy donât you look at your own self before criticizing everyone else? What was it the Good Book said? âWhy, then, do you look at the speck in your brotherâs eye, and pay no attention to the log in your own eye? How dare you say to your brother, âPlease, let me take that speck out of your eye,â when you have a log in your own eye? First take the log out of your own eye, and then you will be able to see clearly to take the speck out of your brotherâs eye.ââ Arianna watched with growing pleasure as the colour rose in Mrs. Rileyâs face. She was a quick learner and previous lessons had taught her that, at least in Mrs. Rileyâs eyes, Scripture from the Good Book should not pass her lips except in prayer. Any other occasion would be considered blasphemous. But she just couldnât pass up the opportunity to show up Mrs. Riley. Maybe she is right in thinking that I am haughty, thought Arianna. However, she only considered this possibility for a moment before dismissing it. Her sharp eyes were quick to pick up the warning signs. Mrs. Rileyâs hands clenched into fists. Her eyes narrowed until they resembled slits. Instead of running away as she was always inclined to do, she braced herself for the beating to come. She knew that running away did not solve matter. It just made things worst. The first blow was sudden and it seemed that Mrs. Riley had poured all her energy into it. Arianna fell to the floor, completely unprepared for the next blow. Blow by blow fell on her. It was completely methodical. It wasnât long before she lost consciousness. Ironic , Arianna thought. She had always told herself that running away solved nothing. Yet she was doing it right now. As she walked through the streets of London, Arianna caught glimpses of urchins and rogues hiding in the shadows. The Ladies of the Night, however, where openly flaunting their wares on the streets. Arianna felt something else other than these common Londoners hiding in the shadow of night. A cold shiver ran down her back as she felt eyes on her. She quickened her pace, hoping to leave those hostile eyes behind her. Funny , thought Arianna. I can hear no following footsteps, yet Iâm positive that someone is following me. She cast a quick glance over her shoulder and saw nothing but shadows. Instead of reassuring her, however, the emptiness just frightened her more and she broke into a run. Even then she heard nothing. As she ran, her untidy mop of hair escaped the ribbon she had tied it in. A sudden sharp wind swept her hair across her face, slapping her cheeks painfully. Still she ran. Still she heard and saw nothing. All of a sudden, Arianna found herself face to face with a brick wall. She spun around and looked about her in search of a weapon she might use to defend herself. There was nothing lying on the ground she could use, but just as she gave up hope, her eyes light upon the boarded up windows of the two buildings forming the alley. Casting her bag aside, she reached up to the nearest window and attempted to pry loose a board. She was still hard at work when the figure appeared at the other end of the alley. It was wrapped in a voluminous coat, making it impossible to distinguish if it was a man or woman. Slowly, it made its way towards her. Arianna increased her efforts and at last one of the boards came loose. It was rotted through at one end, however, causing it to break away leaving a jagged edge. All the better , thought Arianna. At least now I have a potential weapon. The figure laughed as she swung her âweaponâ in front of her. Arianna was rather taken aback. The strangerâs laugh wasnât as harsh as she expected it to be. In fact, she found it sounded sweet and gentle. Yet she could sense the danger hidden behind that laugh. As the figure neared her, Arianna was able to distinguish its features. His skin was unnaturally pale, made even paler by his jet black hair, which was cut in the latest fashion. His dark eyes were cold and expressionless. âWhy donât you put that down before you hurt yourself?â His voice was heavily accented. Definitely not English , thought Arianna. âWhy donât you back off and leave me alone?â retorted Arianna. âWhy are you following me anyway?â The strangerâs lips curled in a feral-like smile. He simply said, âYour anger.â âWhat?â âYou asked me why I was following you and Iâm giving you my reason.â âYouâre following me because Iâm angry?â âWell, itâs not only that. Itâs basically your hatred for everything that attracted me. Itâs like a dark aura youâre emitting. Itâs really irresistible to creatures of the dark like myself.â His answers intrigued her, yet she still held her âweaponâ in front of her, not loosening her grip for a second. âCreatures of the dark?â He smiled his feral-like smile again. He moved closer and as he did Arianna noticed his strange teeth. She gasped. The canines were at least an inch longer than any normal humanâs. âNo,â she breathed. She held onto a thin shred of hope, however. The âweaponâ she wielded was of wood and from what little she knew of vampires, wood could kill them. All she had to do was stake his heart. âTake one more step and Iâll take the liberty of introducing you to the sharp end of this stake here,â threatened Arianna sounding a lot braver than she felt. The vampire laughed again. âNow, really, do you think you can hurt me with that?â âI mean to kill you not hurt you.â The vampire looked amused. He stepped closer and Arianna swung out wildly at him. However, all the running and her efforts in obtaining her âweaponâ had weakened her considerably. He easily side-stepped her swing, but Arianna was determined not to be defeated so easily. Halfway through the swing, she changed directions, swinging her âweaponâ towards the vampire. He was taken aback, and was barely able to get out of the way this time. Arianna heard his shout of rage as her âweaponâ hit him. It hadnât done much damage, however, and the amount of strength she had put in the swing threw her off balance. She fell and, before she could stop him, the vampire had kicked her âweaponâ out of reach. Pulling her up roughly by her hair, he hissed, âThat was a really dumb thing to do. I should kill you for even trying that.â âGo ahead then,â Arianna challenged. The vampireâs angry expression changed to one of puzzlement and amusement. âAre you not afraid of dying?â âNo, Iâd welcome death. Go ahead, kill me.â He smiled that feral-like grin that Arianna hated, and that made her skin crawl, revealing his pointed teeth. âWith pleasure.â Arianna felt his teeth pierce through her skin and felt the pain that accompanied it. He drank deeply. She felt her heartbeat weakening. Slowerâ¦slowerâ¦Before he had finished, Arianna was enveloped by darkness and felt nothing.
